STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 22, 2025
Lori O’Neill
Wellspring Lutheran Services Gaylord
1260 S. Otsego Ave.,
Gaylord, MI, 49735-9587
Re: License #: CB690358779
SI #: 2025SIC0000860
Dear Ms. O’Neill:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan must be completed and routed in CWLM. If you desire technical assistance in
addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000860
Special Investigation Intake Date: July 16, 2025
License #: CB690358779
Licensee Group Organization: Wellspring Lutheran Services
Licensee Designee: Jason Sroufe
Chief Administrator: Delora O’Neill
Agency Name: Wellspring Lutheran Services Gaylord
Agency Address: 1260 S. Otsego Ave
Gaylord, MI 49735-9587
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 01/15/2027
II. METHODOLOGY

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description (1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
contact with children or parents to be a person who has the ability,
experience, education, and training to perform the duties
assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A staff member has shown discriminatory behavior towards a
parent. On 7/16/25 Parent 1 reported he became aware of a
situation in which Foster Care Worker (FCW) told another staff
(Agency Staff) about her bias and discrimination towards Parent 1.
It was reported by Agency Staff to Parent 1 that FCW was making
Parent 1’s life hard and treating him differently from other clients
as Parent 1 reminded FCW of an ex-boyfriend and she could not
stand that the children wanted to live with him.
Investigation Interviews:
Parent 1 was interviewed by phone on 7/23/25. Parent 1 stated
on 7/3/25 he asked Foster Care Worker (FCW) to be honest and
tell him if she made a statement that he reminded her of an ex-
boyfriend, and because of that she wanted to keep his kids away
from him. FCW told Parent 1 she never said that. Parent 1 stated
he believed FCW was lying, as the person who gave him the
information was credible, and FCW had a history of lying to Parent
1, Parent 2, Parent 3, Relative Caregiver, and the court. Parent 1
2

stated he had also been subjected to racism from FCW. However,
he did not provide any specific examples.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via video call on
7/31/25. FCS reported she did not have any concerns about
FCW’s behavior towards Parent 1. However, FCS reported she
was informed by MDHHS Supervisor that it was alleged FCW
made reference to Parent 1 reminding her of an ex-partner and
not trusting him. This was also reported to FCS by Parent 1. The
allegation was also reported by Agency Staff to their supervisor.
FCS addressed the allegation with FCW after the last court
hearing. FCW became emotional and denied making those
statements. FCS stated she had a hard time deciding what was or
was not true. FCW had previously made statements during
supervision about not liking Parent 1’s actions, but never said she
did not like him, or did not want him to get his kids back. FCW
told FCS she wanted Parent 1 to do what was needed to get his
kids back.
Agency Staff was interviewed by phone on 8/1/25. Agency Staff
reported she had been involved with the case for the past two
months to assist with Parent 1’s visitation. At the beginning of the
case, Agency Staff was pulled from a team meeting by FCW and
asked how the first visit went. Agency Staff reported it went well
and there were no concerns. FCW seemed to be looking for
Agency Staff to say something bad about Parent 1. When Agency
Staff mentioned Parent 1 could have supervised the youngest
child a little more closely, FCW said, “see, see, I’m so worried. I
don’t think he’s good with those kids”. Then FCW made
statements that Parent 1 reminded her of her ex-partner, and that
she did not trust him, and he was a narcissist. Agency Staff stated
FCW made her uncomfortable as the statements seemed bias
about Parent 1. However, Agency Staff stated she did not know
much about the case at that point and tried to give FCW the
benefit of the doubt that she must have reason for feeling that
way. After supervising visits for a few more weeks Relative
Caregiver and Parent 1 mentioned some other incidents involving
FCW, which made Agency Staff concerned there was some bias
occurring. Agency Staff also recalled FCW previously describing
Parent 1 as angry, violent and inappropriate when they first
discussed the case. Agency Staff had not observed any violent or
angry behavior from Parent 1 while involved with the case.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via video call on
8/27/25. FCW reported when she was assigned to the case she
was new to the agency and had not worked in foster care or been
3

a case worker before. FCW was told by MDHHS Worker that
Parent 1 was going to be very difficult and ‘a lot’ to deal with.
FCW was informed Parent 1 previously made allegations that
MDHHS Worker was not doing their job. The case then
transferred from MDHHS to the agency and unfortunately as the
case went on, Parent 1’s interactions with FCW were
progressively worse. FCW stated despite aggressive texts and
emails from Parent 1, she continued doing her job as she was
instructed by FCS. FCW stated she never discriminated against
Parent 1, or anyone based on race/ethnicity. FCW reported she
was bewildered about why Agency Staff would make that
allegation. FCW then said she also felt that the Agency Staff
reporting their conversations was a breach of confidentiality and
unprofessional. FCW indicated people say things in the office all
the time, but no one should repeat that information to clients. FCW
stated she did not know Agency Staff well and only met with her
once or twice to brief her on the case before Agency Staff began
assisting with parenting time. FCW recalled she told Agency Staff
that Parent 1 would talk over people, not accept guidance, and
would not accept feedback on how to correct issues as he
seemed to think he knew everything. FCW stated Parent 1 had
narcissistic tendencies, although this was not an official diagnosis.
While FCW denied stating she did not like Parent 1 because he
reminded her of an ex-partner, FCW stated that she may have
compared Parent 1 to an ex-partner as they were both narcissists
and “could not learn” because they “thought they knew
everything”. FCW stated she shared this information with Agency
Staff as a way to help her understand that Parent 1 was difficult
and needed to be worked with and talked to in a “certain way” as
he “cannot learn”. FCW stated her intention was not to imply she
did not like him or wanted him to fail.
Relative Caregiver was interviewed by phone on 8/29/25.
Relative Caregiver reported she did not hear FCW make any
statements about Parent 1 being similar to her ex-partner.
Relative Caregiver stated during home visits with the children, she
never heard FCW indicate she was afraid of Parent 1, or fearful of
the children returning to the care of Parent 1. FCW typically sat in
the kitchen and did not pay attention to the visits occurring in the
living room. FCW would then go to court and report things about
parenting time and Parent 1 that were untrue. Relative Caregiver
stated she did not know why FCW did not like Parent 1, but it was
clear in her opinion that there was bias, as it seemed Parent 1
could never do anything right in FCW’s eyes.
4

MDHHS Worker was interviewed via video call on 9/3/25.
MDHHS Worker reported she had very little contact with FCW
when the case transferred. However, MDHHS Worker recalled
FCW was new, and a more experienced worker probably should
have been assigned. MDHHS Worker stated she informed FCW
that Parent 1 was a “slick talker, a bull-sh**er, never held himself
accountable, played the victim, and would take advantage of the
situation”. MDHHS Worker recalled Parent 1 made some vulgar
statements at times and made veiled threats while she had the
case. MDHHS worker stated FCW never reached out to her about
ways to work with Parent 1.
Attempts were made to interview Parent 2 by phone on 8/26/25,
9/3/25, and 9/9/25. Parent 2 initially seemed interested in
providing information but did not respond to subsequent contacts
to complete an interview.
Attempts were made to interview Parent 3 by phone on 8/26/25
and 8/27/15. However, Parent 3 refused, and indicated her
experience with the agency made her believe they were not
working in her best interest. She refused to answer any other
questions.
On 9/18/25 MDHHS Supervisor was contacted via email.
MDHHS Supervisor clarified they did not hear any direct
statements from FCW about Parent 1. However, they were
informed of the alleged statements by Parent 1. The information
was then discussed with FCS.
Analysis A violation was found. Based on interviews with case participants,
it was determined FCW expressed bias opinions toward Parent 1
potentially due to her own life experiences, which may have
impacted her ability to objectively manage the case and perform
the duties required in her position.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
5

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The social service worker did not work with the parents and
relative caregiver to implement the service plan.
Investigation Interviews:
On 7/16/25 Parent 1 reported to DCWL that he asked for a new
caseworker on several occasions due to concerns regarding FCW
discriminating against and lying about him. Parent 1 reported he
shared these concerns with FCS, his attorney, and the court on
several occasions. Parent 1 stated FCW lied intentionally to keep
Parent 1 from making progress on the treatment plan and to make
him look bad in court. Parent 1 reported because of FCW’s lies he
was not able to advance to unsupervised visits for the duration of
the case. A phone interview occurred with Parent 1 on 7/23/25.
Parent 1 reported he had just learned FCW was no longer with the
agency. Regardless, he wanted to have the investigation
completed. The role of DCWL was clarified for Parent 1, and it
was explained that some of his concerns may need to be
addressed through different departments within the State of
Michigan. Resources were provided to Parent 1 to access those
departments. Parent 1 reported that overall, he could not trust
FCW, and she never supported reunification. Parent 1 reported
the whole experience with foster care was traumatic as FCW did
not include him in anything or allow him to have a say in any plans
made. FCW told Parent 1 that none of the visits or services
completed while in jail “counted”. FCW would not discuss with him
what needed to be done. Parent 1 stated FCW never said
anything encouraging or discussed progress. Parent 1 stated he
felt he was making progress as he had employment, housing, and
a vehicle. But Parent 1 was never sure where he stood with FCW
as she did not review the treatment plan or include him in
development of it. Parent 1 stated he did not always receive
copies of the treatment plan from FCW. In addition, FCW lied in
court reports and service plans about case progress. Parent 1
reported he repeatedly contacted FCS for assistance, but she
always believed what FCW said and would not answer Parent 1’s
questions. Parent 1 requested a new worker multiple times, but a
caseworker change was never considered by the agency to his
knowledge. Parent 1 shared the following specific concerns that
he believed showed FCW was mishandling the case:
Concern 1: FCW falsely reported Parent 1 threatened her, and he
had a gun and ammunition at his home.
6

During the 7/23/25 phone interview with Parent 1, he reported an
incident on 7/3/25 in which FCW was at his home with one of the
children for visitation. Parent 1 asked FCW some questions about
why she lied in the June 2025 court hearing. Parent 1 wanted
clarification about information FCW shared in court, which Parent
1 felt was incorrect. After that visit, FCW called law enforcement
and falsely reported being threatened by Parent 1 and observing a
gun and a box of ammunition at Parent 1’s home. Parent 1
obtained a copy of the police report which indicated he
threatened her and said he “would ruin her”, while he had a gun
and ammunition sitting in plain sight. Parent 1 denied making
threats toward FCW or having a gun. Parent 1 was aware that
having a gun would have been a probation violation. Parent 1
stated that in the police report FCW indicated she had been
supervising visits for the past year, which was incorrect as she
had only supervised for a few months. She was assigned the case
in October 2024, and Parent 1 was incarcerated and not visiting
for the first few months of the case. In the police report FCW
stated she was made to stand in the corner for the duration of the
visit and was belittled by Parent 1. Parent 1 denied that occurred.
In the police report FCW stated she felt threatened and therefore
contacted Parent 2 to pick up the child and end the visit early.
Parent 1 stated that it was untrue as he asked FCW to have
Parent 2 pick up the child early, as Parent 1 did not trust FCW
because of the recent court hearing, and he did not want FCW in
his home any longer. Parent 1 reported had an audio recording of
the exchange, unbeknownst to FCW.
On 7/31/25 Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via
video call. Regarding the incident on July 3, 2025, FCS was not
present. However, she read FCWs statement to police which
indicated Parent 1 was very escalated and FCW observed a gun
case and ammunition in Parent 1’s home.
On 8/1/25 Agency Staff was interviewed by phone. Agency Staff
was part of the Family Reunification Program (FRP) and assisted
with visitation for Parent 1 and the children. Regarding the 7/3/25
incident at Parent 1’s house, Agency Staff reported she was not
present, but she listened to the audio Parent 1 recorded. Agency
Staff stated Parent 1 did not sound threatening or violent in the
audio and there was no mention of a gun. Agency Staff stated she
had never observed Parent 1 to have a gun or ammunition.
On 8/27/25 FCW was interviewed via video call. FCW reported on
7/3/25 she was at Parent 1’s home for visitation. Parent 1 was
very hostile and escalated, poking his finger in her face while he
7

was holding the toddler child. FCW felt Parent 1 was manic,
slurring his words, muttering, berating and criticizing the worker.
Then his mood would rapidly shift, and he would play with his child
for a while. FCW tried to contact the agency for support for the
duration of the two-hour visit. FCW stated she did not feel safe,
but no one from the agency responded to her requests for help.
FCW suspected Parent 1 was on substances. FCW recalled one
of the children once told her that Parent 1 previously had a gun.
After the visit was over, FCW contacted the police for a wellness
check as she was concerned about Parent 1. When asked if she
reported seeing a gun, FCW stated she did not tell the police she
saw a gun. FCW told police she saw something that looked like it
could be for ammunition, but she could not confirm.
After the holiday weekend, FCW returned to work and
administration acted like it was business as normal. FCW was
instructed to continue supervising parenting time in the home,
even though she did not feel safe. After FCW provided details of
the incident, Program Manager agreed FCW would not need to go
back into the home again. However, FCW was then placed on the
schedule to supervise parenting time at Parent 1’s house. FCS
told FCW she could go with another person. FCW felt it was
unsafe, even with another person. FCW felt unsupported,
especially when FCS asked FCW what she did to “set him off”. It
felt like FCS was implying the situation was FCW’s fault. FCW
reported she previously felt unsupported in this case when FCS
told her that sometimes cases are just hard and she needed to
figure it out, but did not offer ways to provide support.
On 8/29/25 Relative Caregiver was interviewed by phone.
Relative Caregiver was not present for the 7/3/25 incident.
However, Relative Caregiver stated FCW never expressed any
concern about the children’s safety or indicated she believed
Parent 1 was dangerous or under the influence. Which made it
concerning that she would allege such things to law enforcement.
Relative Caregiver stated neither of the children ever mentioned
Parent 1 owned a gun. Relative Caregiver believed FCW’s report
about one of the kids telling her there was a gun, then seeing a
suspected gun, was false.
On 9/10/25 Administrator provided written responses to some
questions from DCWL via email, as Program Manager was on an
extended leave of absence. Regarding FCW stating that she sent
texts to several staff for assistance during the 7/3/25 visit and did
not receive a response, Administrator reported Program Manager
responded via text and instructed FCW to leave. FCW responded
that she was unable to leave. Per Administrator, the Program
8

Manager had a phone call with FCW directly after the visit to
discuss the situation. Regarding FCW supervising visits in Parent
1’s home after that incident, Program Manager told FCW she
would not have to return to the home. However, it was
determined FCW and another staff could still supervise parenting
time. FCW was asked by FCS if she felt comfortable supervising
with another person present. FCW responded that she would be
fine with that. The agency was working with the prosecutor to file a
motion with the court to change the location of visits to a public
place or MDHHS. FCW resigned from the agency before the
motion could be filed.
Attempts were made to interview Parent 2 by phone on 8/26/25,
9/3/25, and 9/9/25. Parent 2 initially seemed interested in
providing information but did not respond to subsequent contacts
to complete an interview.
Video review:
Parent 1 reported he had a video of the visit at his home on
7/3/25. However, a working file of the video was not received by
DCWL.
Documents reviewed:
• Case assigned to agency and Foster Care Worker on
10/4/24.
• 7/3/25 Police Report filed by FCW. FCW reported she was
threatened and intimidated by Parent 1 during a supervised
visit. FCW reported Parent 1 was acting abnormally, very
angry, and it made her uncomfortable. FCW stated Parent
1 had made it clear over the past year that he did not like
her. During the visit Parent 1 was swearing and belittling
her. Parent 1 stated that FCW would “get what’s coming to
her”. FCW ended the visit early by having the child’s
mother pick him up. FCW believed Parent 1 was under the
influence. FCW reported she believed Parent 1 had a
firearm in his possession and saw what she believed to be
a plastic gun case. FCW clarified she did not see a gun,
just a case.
• Summary of case contact dated 7/3/25 authored by FCW.
Parenting time at Parent 1’s home. FCW reported details of
a tense exchange with Parent 1 as he vented frustration
with the case. Parent 1 told FCW she could not sit on his
furniture; she could stand for the visit and not touch any of
his stuff. Parent 1 confronted FCW about an allegation that
was reported to MDHHS of Parent 1 traveling out of state
with Relative Caregiver and a child. Parent 1 believed FCW
9

was responsible for this false complaint. FCW text Program
Manager that she needed help ASAP at 5:05PM. FCW text
another staff at 5:14PM requesting help ASAP. Parent 1
said he’d “spend every last dollar to get (FCW) fired”. FCW
was scared and crying but did not receive a response from
agency staff. Parent 1 complained about the distance he
needed to travel for drug screens to be compliant and
stated he did not trust FCW. FCW received a text from
Program Manager at 5:49PM to end the visit if she felt
threatened. FCW responded at 5:52PM there was no easy
way to leave without escalating the situation. No response
was received. At 6:16PM Parent 1 told FCW she could go
ahead and sit. At 6:27PM FCW text FCS requesting help
but did not receive a response. Parent 1 was very
accusatory in his conversation with FCW. FCW believed
Parent 1 was under the influence as he was verbally
aggressive towards FCW. FCW observed what appeared to
be ammunition alongside a black case. One of the children
previously told FCW Parent 1 had a gun when they lived
somewhere else. Parent 1 yelled that he wanted FCW out
of his house. FCW text Parent 2 and requested she pick up
the child immediately. Parent 1 continued speaking to FCW
in an aggressive tone. The child appeared scared. Parent 2
arrived and FCW rushed out the door and got in her car.
FCW observed Parent 2 buckle the child in the car seat and
prepare to leave. FCW then left before Parent 2 left with the
child.
Concern 2: FCW falsely reported in court that she discussed
guardianship with Parent 1 and Relative Caregiver.
In the phone interview on 7/23/25, Parent 1 reported FCW never
discussed Guardianship with him.
On 8/27/25 an interview was completed with FCW via video call.
FCW reported being with the agency for approximately one year
and leaving suddenly due to a lack of support from the agency
and concerns for how the job impacted her health. FCW stated
she received guidance from MDHHS and the agency, but it was
hard to know who to listen to. At times MDHHS was very assertive
in how they wanted things done, which was different from what the
agency wanted. At one-point MDHHS wanted termination, while
the agency wanted to look toward guardianship for a goal. FCW
reported requesting a goal change to guardianship in court. FCW
stated she discussed guardianship with Relative Caregiver but not
10

with Parent 1. FCW could not recall details of their discussion with
Relative Caregiver about guardianship.
In the 8/29/25 phone interview Relative Caregiver reported she
attended all hearings for this case and observed FCW to report
false information on more than one occasion. In June 2025 FCW
reported to court that she spoke with Parent 1 and Relative
Caregiver at length about guardianship of the youth. When
questioned by court if both types of guardianship were discussed,
FCW said yes and told court that Relative Caregiver agreed to
Juvenile Guardianship. Court asked FCW if Relative Caregiver
was aware that she would no longer receive a foster care payment
and would not qualify for state assistance payments. FCW
answered yes. Relative Caregiver stated she never had a
conversation with FCW about guardianship and never agreed to
guardianship knowing there would be no financial assistance. At a
subsequent visit to the home, Relative Caregiver confronted FCW.
FCW did not explain why she lied, but FCW stated that she did not
even know there were two types of guardianship until that moment
in court. When pressed about why she lied, FCW did not have an
answer.
Documents reviewed:
Review of case record in MiSACWIS
• No case contacts were found documenting discussion of
guardianship between FCW and Relative Caregiver or
Parent 1.
• No FTM or TDM regarding a goal change to guardianship
was located in the file.
Video recording of 6/11/25 court hearing
FCW requested a goal change to guardianship. FCW stated she
spoke with Relative Caregiver, who agreed that Juvenile
Guardianship should be the goal. FCW was asked if Relative
Caregiver understood it would be Juvenile and not be Subsidized
Guardianship and if she was willing to do guardianship without
any state financial assistance and also lose the foster care
payments. FCW said Relative Caregiver was aware and agreed to
that. When asked if Relative Caregiver was close to being
licensed, as was required, FCW stated Relative Caregiver had
stopped the licensing process and did not plan to continue. FCW
was questioned by the court why she would recommend Juvenile
Guardianship if Relative Caregiver was unwilling to become
licensed. FCW acknowledged it was not a viable plan and
discussed looking for placement for the child with relatives out of
state but indicated it would be best for the child to remain in
11

current placement as the goal was still reunification. The court did
not understand FCW’s recommendation and stated the goal would
not be changed to Guardianship. However, the request was noted.
Concern 3: FCW incorrectly stated in court that Parent 1 was not
employed, had positive drug screens, and refused to screen.
In a phone interview on 7/23/25, Parent 1 reported that he may
have missed some screens as FCW would not answer his phone
calls to tell him when and where to screen. FCW also did not
administer some drug screens correctly, as she did not secure the
top with the sticky label as required.
During the 7/31/25 video call interview, FCS reported Parent 1
and Relative Caregiver contacted her on numerous occasions to
express concerns about FCW. FCS had several conversations
with FCW and viewed a lot of case documentation to verify
information reported in service plans and court reports was
accurate. FCS noted Parent 1 had been difficult to work with and
often sent verbally aggressive emails to FCW. FCS stated she
was not aware of any instances where FCW lied in court.
Regarding employment, FCS clarified that FCW did not report
Parent 1 lacked employment, she reported Parent 1 did not
provide her with proof of employment. Regarding drug screens,
FCS stated FCW reported accurately that Parent 1 had not done
drug screens with the agency. FCS was aware Parent 1 had
completed weekly drug screens through a substance abuse
treatment provider. Regarding the allegation that FCW did not
answer calls for drug screens, FCS stated that beginning March
2025, Parent 1 was required to call a different number, then email
his attorney and MDHHHS to notify them if he had to screen that
day. Parent 1 admitted to FCW he was not doing those things
consistently. Prior to March 2025, Parent 1 was not required to
call FCW. FCW would plan to randomly screen him at parenting
time, or text him to come in. FCS reported Parent 1 never
completed drug screens with the FCW or the agency. However,
she found a note in the file indicating on 12/23/24 the observer
section of a drug screen was not completed thoroughly by FCW.
FCS stated there was no way to find out what happened as there
was no one else present and FCW would have been the only
person to know.
During the 8/27/25 video call, FCW stated Parent 1 accused her of
lying in court. FCW stated she could only report information she
could verify and at the time she did not have employment
verification for Parent 1, so she could not report that he was
12

working. FCW stated Parent 1 had reportedly started a business
and was self-employed. FCW stated Parent 1 provided a 2019
document to show the business was created but did not provide
documentation the business was still running. FCW reported she
always provided accurate information to court, such as Parent 1
not complying with anger management class, parenting class,
AA/NA meetings, or DV counseling. These services were outlined
in the PATP. However, FCW admitted she had not been able to
review the PATP with Parent 1 or discuss services or referrals.
FCW reported Parent 1 was required to participate in drug
screens. Parent 1 refused to participate in screens administered
by FCW or FCS. Parent 1 initially completed two screens in
December 2024 with FCW, but none after. FCW reported she
administered these screens after she received training from the
agency to do so. FCW admitted she was unaware of the
requirement to have the donor cross hatch the stickers over the
vial for security. FCW heard this from another worker sometime
after she had already been administering screens. FCW stated
this was likely covered in training, but she could not remember.
FCW noted that the screens she completed with Parent 1 may not
have been done correctly, but they were all negative. Subsequent
screens were completed at a MDHHS office. Parent 1 was
required to call the automated system by 5:00AM and if his color
was called, he had to screen between 12:00-1:00PM. Parent 1
told FCW he called a few times but never attended because he
worked during that time. FCW stated Parent 1 was never required
to call her for screens and she never blocked his number.
Additionally, FCW reported that the medical provider reported
Parent 1 tampered with a drug screen. FCW indicated there was
documentation on file for this.
On 8/29/25 Relative Caregiver was interviewed by phone.
Relative Caregiver reported she was aware Parent 1 was working
full time and overtime. Relative Caregiver stated she did not have
any firsthand knowledge about Parent 1’s drug screens or if they
were accurately reported to court. However, Relative Caregiver
reported she had not observed Parent 1 to be under the influence,
or showing any concerning behavior. She had no reason to
suspect he was using substances again. Relative Caregiver stated
she knew what he was like under the influence before, and she
did not have any concerns at this time.
Documents reviewed:
Personnel file for Foster Care Worker

information FCW reported she obtained from the physician’s office
since February 2025 was a lie.

during a Team Decision Making Meeting (TDM) Parent 1 said he
would sign anything. At a later TDM he said he did not receive

certain what happened. FCW reported to FCS that Parent 1
signed the releases at a later date.

compliant in this area. FCW recalled Parent 1 signed release

treatment and drug screens, and another provider. FCW stated

indicated she believed Parent 1 relapsed in March 2025. FCW did
not provide any detail as to why she believed this.

FCW reported that Parent 1 admitted to his doctor that he
relapsed in March 2025.

Concern 5: FCW allowed a child to travel out of state without
parental consent.
In a phone interview on 7/23/25, Parent 1 reported that in June
2025 FCW falsely reported consent for travel and presented that
information to MDHHS and court. After the child had already left
out of state, FCW asked Parent 1 to sign consent forms.
During the 7/31/25 video call, FCS stated Relative Caregiver only
gave FCW a little over a week notice about the trip. Per FCW,
Relative Caregiver told FCW that Parent 1 was aware of the trip.
FCW reportedly contacted Parent 1 to schedule a visit to sign the
form. FCW reportedly notified MDHHS and court but did not
receive a response. The day after they left, a complaint came into
MDHHS indicating no one knew about the travel. When contacted,
Parent 1 stated he knew about the trip but did not want to sign the
consent form. Parent 3 did not respond to worker’s request for
consent.
During the 8/27/25 interview FCW stated Relative Caregiver
contacted her around June 13th, with plans to travel out of state on
June 22nd. FCW was instructed by FCS to get an itinerary from
Relative Caregiver to provide to court, which she did. The
following week MDHHS requested a different document, which
FCW was not previously aware of. MDHHS provided the form and
requested signatures from the parents. FCW then learned Parent
3 was in Arizona and refused to communicate with FCW. FCW
reported communication attempts were documented in
MiSACWIS. FCW emailed Parent 1 about the travel dates. Parent
1 did not necessarily provide approval, but he acknowledged that
parenting time would need to be rescheduled due to the trip. FCW
told MDHHS that Parent 1 acknowledged he was aware of the
travel and MDHHS said they would see if court would count that
as consent. MDHHS then responded they needed the signed
consent form. FCW was instructed by FCS to have Parent 1 sign
16

the travel consent form. Parent 1 refused to sign the form when he
received it on 6/24/25, as the youth had already been out of state
since 6/20/25. FCW stated she did not ask Parent 1 to backdate
the form. FCW reported she was not aware of the form prior to
that date, or she would have tried to get it signed earlier. FCW
also reported she received the form late on a Friday and the
agency told her she could not send emails on nights or weekends,
so she had to wait until Monday 6/24/25.
During the 8/29/25 phone interview Relative Caregiver stated she
informed FCW of the trip on 6/13/25. Relative Caregiver stated
she never told FCW they had verbal permission from Parent 1. On
6/17/25 FCW told Relative Caregiver that she had verbal
permission from Parent 3. However, on 6/20/25 FCW was at
Relative Caregiver’s house and asked if she knew how to reach
Parent 3, as she had not had any contact with her.
On 9/10/25 Administrator provided written responses to some
questions from DCWL via email, as Program Manager was on an
extended leave of absence. Regarding the out of state travel,
FCW was given guidance by FCS to obtain a detailed itinerary.
FCW contacted the prosecutor and GAL on 6/16/25 to request
permission to travel. On 6/17/25 Parent 1 sent an email indicating
he was aware of the travel. On 6/19/25 the prosecutor reported
they had not received anything from FCW and advised she
needed to contact MDHHS. On 6/19/25 FCS responded and
directed FCW to get something in writing from both parents giving
their consent. FCS provided policy to FCW regarding travel and
cc’d MDHHS Supervisor. MDHHS Supervisor provided their
county specific form to FCW on 6/20/25. On 6/24/25 FCW sent the
form to Parent 1. On 6/24/25 FCW and FCS received an email
from Parent 1 refusing to sign the form since the child was already
out of state.
Attempts were made to interview Parent 3 by phone on 8/26/25
and 8/27/15. However, Parent 3 refused, and indicated her
experience with the agency made her believe they were not
working in her best interest. She refused to answer any other
questions.

Concern 6:
FCW entered Relative Caregiver’s home without permission, by
using a hidden spare key.
During the 7/31/25 video call, FCS was asked if FCW ever
entered Relative Caregiver’s home without permission, while the
caregiver was not present. FCS stated this did happen. FCW was
placed on disciplinary action in November 2024 due to the
incident. FCW told FCS that she arrived at the home before the
relative. The 9-year-old child that was with FCW got out of the car,
used the hidden key and entered the home before FCW could
stop him. The child said it was okay and FCW believed him.
Relative Caregiver arrived at the home and was very unhappy.
FCW understood why she should not have done that.
During the 8/27/25 interview with FCW, she reported that she did
enter Relative Caregiver’s home without permission. FCW arrived
at the house and Relative Caregiver was not there yet. One youth
said he knew where the key was and that it was ok to go in. He
was about 9 years old at the time. FCW stated she carried the 1-
year-old into the doorway and placed him in the walker by the
18

door. The other child went in and FCW waited outside. When
asked if she was concerned about the child being in the home
unsupervised, FCW stated she could see him from the door.
Relative Caregiver arrived home a few minutes later and was
upset. FCW spoke with her for about an hour, apologizing, and
everything seemed ok. Two months later, FCS and Program
Manager asked FCW about the incident, as they received a
grievance. FCW admitted he should have said no to the child and
called Relative Caregiver. FCW stated she also should have
notified the agency about the incident when it happened.
During the 8/29/25 phone interview Relative Caregiver recalled
the incident. Relative Caregiver was running late from work that
day and when she pulled into the driveway, she was surprised to
see FCWs car with no one in it. Relative Caregiver walked up to
the house and FCW came out from inside the house. FCW met
Relative Caregiver at the door and explained that the 9-year-old
child had used the spare key to get in. Relative Caregiver told
FCW that was unacceptable. Relative Caregiver later emailed
FCS about the incident. FCS replied that to her knowledge FCW
did not enter the home but waited outside the door. Relative
Caregiver let FCS know that it was a lie, as she observed FCW in
the house, and FCW told her about how the 1-year-old child was
really fast and she had to chase him down the hall to get him into
the walker.

heard disagreeing with this. FCW also reported that the family

she wanted Parent 2 to have more supervised visits before

FCW that she found troublesome while involved in the case. FCW
told Agency Staff that a court order stated Parent 1 and Parent 2

worker was responsible for scheduling services. She did not

family camping and due to the proximity of Relative Caregiver’s

During the 8/29/25 phone interview Relative Caregiver reported
she recalled an unusual incident once in court. FCW testified that
during a supervised visit with Parent 3 the youth saw a tent in the
wood and wanted to go look at it, but Parent 3 and FCW said no.
Relative Caregiver stated this was different than what FCW
originally told her when the incident happened. The original story
from FCW was that the child and Parent 3 went to look at the tent,
while FCW stayed behind. This was confirmed to Relative
Caregiver by the child. Relative Caregiver thought this was an odd
thing to lie about in court and did not understand FCWs reasoning.
Relative Caregiver recalled another situation in which Parent 1
was on a video call with the older child. Parent 1 observed the

22

he was allowed to drink coffee and that Relative Caregiver let him
drink it all the time. Relative Caregiver said that was absolutely not
true, and that she did not drink coffee or even keep it in the house.
It made her very uncomfortable how easily FCW lied in that

paperwork last minute and did not seem informed of policies. For
example, the children received Christmas gifts from Operation
Good Cheer. FCW failed to let Relative Caregiver know until after
the due date passed, that thank you notes had to be submitted.
Overall, Relative Caregiver felt that FCW would nitpick at Parent
1’s abilities and report things about parenting time such as when
he forgot to put the lock on the stroller wheels at the park. But
FCW would never report all of the good things Parent 1 did.
Relative Caregiver noted FCW likely did not notice the positive as
she rarely paid attention to the visits and often sat in the kitchen
while Parent 1 and the kids visited in the living room. Relative
Caregiver said it appeared that FCW was always looking for the
worst in Parent 1 and tearing him down. FCW did not advocate for
the family or provide resources when they asked for help. It was
uncomfortable to have her in the home a she seemed to want the
kids to be removed from their parents permanently. Overall,
Relative Caregiver reported FCW did not do an adequate job and

Concern 9: FCW lied about Parent 3, withheld visits with the
children, and did not provide resources when facing
homelessness.
In a phone interview on 7/23/25, Parent 1 reported that FCW’s
actions resulted in Parent 3 feeling hopeless about reunification
and leaving the state. Parent 1 stated that Parent 3 was not good
at advocating for herself and was essentially bullied by FCW into
giving up. Because of that, Parent 3 did not trust the agency or
MDHHS and did not fight for her rights.
Attempts were made to interview Parent 3 by phone on 8/26/25
and 8/27/15. However, Parent 3 refused, and indicated her
experience with the agency made her believe they were not
working in her best interest. She refused to answer any other
questions.
Attempts were made to interview Parent 2 by phone on 8/26/25,
9/3/25, and 9/9/25 to corroborate information presented by Parent
1. Parent 2 initially seemed interested in providing information but
did not respond to subsequent contacts to complete an interview.
Analysis A violation was found. Based on interviews with case members,
audio from a recent court hearing, and a review of documents it
was determined Foster Care Worker was not adequately working
directly with the family to develop and implement the service plan.
The incomplete and missing documentation, and examples of
incorrect or misrepresented information are not consistent with
what is expected of a case manager working with children,
parents, and relative caregivers toward reunification.
Conclusion Violation Established
25

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
Section (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the
Description foster parents in the development of service plans to enable the
parent or parents and foster parents to understand the plan for the
child and the parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to
and review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or
parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the child and the
child's family is confidential.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency did not discuss, review or provide copies of treatment
plans to parents.
Investigation Interviews:
Parent 1 was interviewed by phone on 7/23/25. Parent 1 reported
Foster Care Worker (FCW) did not include him in anything or
allow him to have a say in any plans made. Parent 1 stated he felt
he was making progress as he had employment, housing, and a
vehicle. But Parent 1 was never sure where he stood with FCW as
she did not review the treatment plan or include him in
development of it. Parent 1 stated he did not always receive
copies of the treatment plan from FCW.
Attempts were made to interview Parent 2 by phone on 8/26/25,
9/3/25, and 9/9/25. Parent 2 initially seemed interested in
providing information but did not respond to subsequent contacts
to complete an interview.
Attempts were made to interview Parent 3 by phone on 8/26/25
and 8/27/15. However, Parent 3 refused, and indicated her
experience with the agency made her believe they were not
working in her best interest. She refused to answer any other
questions.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via video call on
7/31/25. FCS indicated she believed Parent Agency Treatment
Plans (PATP) were mailed to Parent 1 while incarcerated. FCS
indicated she believed documentation was uploaded. However,
she also acknowledged some documents were missing.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via video call on
8/27/25. FCW reported that Parent 1 was provided with the first
26

PATP completed by the agency, via mail, while he was
incarcerated. Parent 1 signed and returned the PATP with notes
disagreeing with information on it. FCW reported she did not
review any subsequent PATPs with Parent 1. FCW stated she did
not schedule any meetings to review the PATPs with Parent 1.
FCW reported that the agency told her to only text or email Parent
1, therefore she did not schedule any phone calls or meetings to
review and discuss the treatment plans. FCW stated she saw
Parent 1 in person during weekly parenting time. However, FCW
did not want to review the PATP during parenting time. FCW did
not plan time before or after parenting time to meet with Parent 1.
FCW stated Parent 1 was correct, he was not included in
development or review of the PATP. FCW stated she wished they
could have sat down and discussed the case, but there was not a
good opportunity to do so as they did not have a good working
relationship.
Documents reviewed
The MiSACWIS case record was reviewed for documentation to
indicate PATPs were developed, reviewed with, and provided to
Parent 1.
• Case assigned to agency and Foster Care Worker on
10/4/24.
• PATP 9/29/24-12/27/24: Parent 1, Parent 2 and Parent 3
were identified as participating. However, PATPs were not
signed by any parents. There were no documents uploaded
to indicate PATPs were provided to or reviewed with
Parents 2 or Parent 3 or Relative Caregiver. There was an
email dated 1/9/25 indicating the PATP was sent to Parent
1, but no indication it was discussed/reviewed.
• PATP 12/28/24-3/27/25: Parent 1, Parent 2 and Parent 3
were identified as participating. There were no documents
uploaded to indicate PATPs were provided to or reviewed
with Parent 2 or Parent 3. A document indicating it was a
“condensed version of the MDHHS MiSACWIS Parent
Agency Treatment Plan” for 12/27/24-3/27/24, was signed
by Parent 1 on 3/8/25 under a line stating, “By signing
below, I acknowledge that I received a copy of this
document on the date noted”. A case contact by Foster
Care Worker indicated this document was mailed to Parent
1 on 2/28/25. However, the 3/27/25 PATP was not
approved by Foster Care Supervisor until 4/11/25.
• PATP 3/27/25-6/24/25. Parent 1, Parent 2 and Parent 3
were identified as participating. The PATP was signed by
Parent 2 on 8/7/25. Parent 2 indicated she received a copy
of the PATP and did not indicate if she participated in
27

development of the plan. The PATP was signed by Relative
Caregiver on 7/29/25. Relative Caregiver indicated she
received a copy of the PATP and did not indicate if she
participated in development of the plan. The PATP for
Parent 3 indicated it could not be provided as Parent 3 was
out of state and would not provide contact information. A
signed PATP was not uploaded for Parent 1. However, a
case contact from 8/25/25 indicated the Chief Administrator
met with Parent 1 and provided a copy, which he declined
to sign.
• Case contacts were reviewed. There was no
documentation found to indicate Parent 1 was involved in
development of the PATPs.
• The PATP referenced by FCW in the 8/27/25 interview,
with notes from Parent 1 stating information was incorrect,
and could not be verified as it was not found to be uploaded
in MiSACWIS.
• Participation in case planning through Family Team
Meetings (FTM) or Team Decision Making Meeting (TDM)
was reviewed and found to be inconsistent: Parent 2
participated in a TDM on 11/7/24 and 2/27/25 and FTMs on
12/17/24 and 9/5/25. Parent 3 participated in a TDM on
12/9/24. Parent 1 participated in a TDM on12/11/24 and
5/1/25.
Analysis A violation was found. Based on interviews and documents
reviewed, it was determined Foster Care Worker did not
consistently involve the parents in case planning. Nor did she
consistently review the PATPs or provide copies to the parents or
caregiver.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
Section (3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing agency
Description to another child placing agency, a modified service plan must be
completed within 30 calendar days of the change in agency
responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days. The plan
must address why the agency responsibility changed and whether
there are any modifications to existing service plans.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency did not complete a timely modified service plan after
accepting the case.
28

Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via video call on
8/27/25. During the interview FCW reported the agency received
the case in October 2024 and the first USP was completed for
Parent 1 in December 2024. FCW reported that a 30-day service
plan was not completed.
Documents reviewed
The MiSACWIS case record was reviewed for documentation
related to Updated Service Plans (USP).
• Case assigned to agency and Foster Care Worker on
10/4/24.
• The first USP/PATP completed by the agency was for the
review period of 9/29/24-12/27/24. The report was
completed on 12/27/24 and approved on 12/31/24.
Analysis A violation was found. A modified service plan was not completed
within 30 days of case transfer.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12210 Grievance handling
Section An agency shall have a written grievance handling procedure as
Description mandated by section 8a of the foster care and adoption services
act, 1994 PA 203, MCL 722.958a, and known as the “foster
parent’s bill of rights law.”
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency did not respond to a grievance submitted by Parent 1.
Investigation Interviews:
In a phone interview on 7/23/25, Parent 1 reported he filed a
grievance in February 2025 regarding his concerns. The
grievance was submitted to FCS. Parent 1 was never contacted
by the agency and did not receive a written response to the
grievance.
During the 7/31/25 video call FCS reported that throughout the
case Parent 1 contacted her several times. Most recently on
7/23/25 in which he asked a lot of questions, FCS replied 7/23/25
that she would send a response at a later time. As of 7/31/25 FCS
reported she had not yet replied. FCS stated Parent 1 expressed
the same concerns over and over, which she had already
addressed numerous time, and felt that he would not be satisfied
with any response. FCS clarified that she was not able to give
29

Parent 1 all of the details that he was looking for. FCS was aware
that Parent 1 had filed a grievance. The grievance was forwarded
to Program Manager and FCS was unsure what happened after
that. FCS stated Parent 1 had requested a new worker multiple
times. FCS discussed this request with Program Manager and
MDHHS, but decided a new worker was not needed as FCW was
not the concern. However, as FCW left her position at the
beginning of this investigation, the case was reassigned to
Program Manager. FCW put in her notice of resignation and
immediately left. FCS believed it was a result of the 7/3/25
incident. FCS stated that overall, she did not have any concerns
about FCW’s performance with this case. FCS supervised FCW
the entire time she was with the agency.
During the 8/27/25 video call FCW reported she was aware that
Parent 1 filed a grievance of all of his concerns. FCW was not
sure who addressed the grievance as no one formally spoke with
her about it. FCW stated she was aware Parent 1 requested a
new worker several times, but the agency said they felt a new
worker would not fix the issue.
On 9/10/25 Administrator provided written responses to some
questions from DCWL via email, as Program Manager was on an
extended leave of absence. Administrator reported the agency
did receive a grievance form from Parent 1 on or around 2/27/25.
Program Manager attempted to contact Parent 1 to discuss the
grievance, but he did not respond to her attempts. Administrator
confirmed the agency’s typical practice is not to reassign cases
when a parent becomes upset. The agency will first work with
everyone involved to repair the relationship.
Documents reviewed
• Grievance form dated 2/27/25, authored by Parent 1 and
emailed to FCW.
• Emails from Parent 1 to the agency, his attorney, and
MDHHS from 1/10/25, 2/4/25, 2/27/25, 3/13/24, 5/27/25,
6/17/25, 6/24/25. 6/26/25, 7/1/25 and 7/10/25 reported
concerns Parent 1 had regarding FCW. Concerns included:
FCW not providing release forms then reporting Parent 1
was not compliant with signing them, FCW incorrectly
administering drug screens by not putting the safety strop
over the top, FCW worker entering Relative Caregiver’s
home while they were not present, Parent 1 filed a
grievance and did not receive a response, FCW attempting
to change parenting time to a time that does not work for
him, FCW falsely reporting Parent 1 and Parent 3 gave
30

verbal permission for youth to travel out of state, FCW told
Relative Caregiver she was camping near their home so
she could spy on them, and multiple requests for a new
caseworker.
• MiSACWIS case contacts and documents were reviewed.
There was no indication the agency discussed the
grievance with Parent 1.
• The agency’s grievance policy states, “all clients, including
parents of minors and Wellspring Lutheran Services’ foster
parents, have the option of utilizing the Complaint
Resolution Procedure when they are dissatisfied with the
agency’s services.” In summary the procedure states the
client is to discuss concerns with the supervisor and if a
resolution is not achieved, the client may file a Complaint
Resolution Form. The Program Manager will acknowledge
receipt of the form in writing to the client within two days
and will begin to investigate the complaint. Clients will
receive written notification of action taken within 30 days of
receipt of the written complaint.
Analysis A violation was found as the agency did not follow their grievance
policy to provide a written notification of action within 30 days.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A Corrective Action Plan is required.
